If you add dicheezium during the demorphation stage, the precipitate will retain more bisulphic trions, which, due to their low pervessibility, will render more of the silver, in the form of fractons. It was common in the past for people to trim or grind the edges of coins in order to remove valuable metal whilst still maintaining the value of the coin itself as currency. This was especially common when coins were pure silver or gold.
They realised that coins where becoming smaller in diameter over time.
Solution? The introduction of ridges or ribs around the coin's edge which meant that coins that had been shaved or ground down could be identified.

Who invented the ribs and ridges on the coins to prevent coin shaving??? Sir Isaac Newton.

https://www.google.com/url?sa=i&url=http%3A%2F%2Fnowiknow.com%2Fwhy-some-coins-have-ridges%2F&psig=AOvVaw2AySfDpP-xv8OKyO2YHl26&ust=1610409363804000&source=images&cd=vfe&ved=0CAIQjRxqFwoTCMiN0cbIku4CFQAAAAAdAAAAABAD

You should stop using filter paper because you are loosing products that way, instead use a centrifuge. If you don't want to buy one, best way to do it is with a bicycle. Just flip a bicycle upside down, attach vials and/or test tubes with lids, use electrical tape to tape spokes very well, (duct tape leaves glue/sticky residue). Start slowly to spin it. You don't any to fly off and hit you. Let me know if you it works and you get a better yield. Filter paper is only good for filtering stuff to throw out, but not very good for collecting product(s). You're loosing product(s) in the fibers in paper.

Actually, 1967 centennial quarter shown in the video has two varieties; 50% silver and 80% silver. You cannot tell with naked eye which is which. Coin dealers up here just say "65%" since the 50% and 80% silver varieties are half half, and it's not worth time for them to go through everything one by one with the machine.

Instead of using an excess of nitic acid, you should have made sure there was an excess of silver at the end of the reaction. This way, the solution will only contain silver nitrate and copper nitrate, with no unreacted nitric acid to dissolve the copper and silver in the next step. Just filter off the unreacted metal and use copper to cement out the silver powder.

Don't do this with local currency unless your law is different than most. In most countries, it is illegal to convert currency into it's raw metal. Crushing and stamping into other things is usually ok, but melting or chemical extraction is usually a violation.

After the first silver extraction, add salt or hydrochloric acid to precipitate AgCl.  Filter.  To the AgCl, add NaOH in crucible and fire.  Then add carbon powder and fire again to get silver metal missed in the 1st extraction.  Some borax will help coalesce the silver.  Dump while molten as you did first and wash in water to dissolve the borax & salt.

Instead of using copper wire to precipitate the silver out, you could have just used something containing chlorine (sodium chloride, bleach, etc...).  You'll drop out silver chloride, which can be melted, releasing chlorine gas and leaving near pure silver.  It's less expensive and easier to do than the copper wire method, but both will work. I found another way to do this, though slower - use HCl mixed with H2O2.  I used 35% H2O2 but it is not required, but the reaction runs faster.  Note also H2O2 at high concentrations is dangerous, particularly to eyes - use caution.  The end result was CuClx (and probably some ZnCl2) in solution (which you can later evaporate to capture) and a silver powder on the bottom of the beaker.  I tested it on some 10% silver coins from Mexico to get this result.

I made silver nitrate by dissolving sterling silver (92.5% Ag 7.5% Cu I think) and then adding ethanol to precipitate the AgNO3 leaving the copper in solution. One could then make Silver by decomposing the AgNO3 with heat.

However, I read in a small monograph on purification methods (I think), that using ethanol in this way could result in explosive contaminants. To my eternal regret I failed to buy this book and I don't know its name.

If you could comment on this or know of such a book I would be most interested to hear. Thanks


OK I did some research and found "Silver nitrate and ethanol may give silver fulminate" - in Purification of Laboratory Chemicals (Sixth Edition) - Wilfred L.F. Armarego and Christina Li Lin Chai - ISBN: 978-1-85617-567-8


While not the book I was looking for it looks very useful.

Their is a way to remove the Silver easily from a melting crucible. If you put quite a bit of ground Borax into the crucible and heat it till it goes like glass beforehand if you are quick and remove the Silver quickly it will be easily removed.
However, this may leave a residue of glass like borax on the silver, but this is easily removed with a dilute liquid of sulfuric acid and water "jewellers pickle" (10/1). But if you are just doing a small amount, charred wood is good ;-)

You should use sodium chloride to precipitate silver chloride, ad than melt it with soda.
4AgCl + 2Na2CO3 = 4Ag + 4NaCl + 2CO2 + O2
